<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">The Crystal Palace  
1871  
Oil on canvas; 47 × 73.2 cm (18 1/2 × 28 3/4 in.)  
Signed and dated: C. Pissarro 1871 (lower left, in warm-gray paint)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Mr. and Mrs. B. E. Bensinger, 1972.1164

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">1870 and 1871 were among the most difficult years of Pissarro’s life. He had worked happily and productively in Louveciennes until the onset of the Franco-Prussian War, but, by early September 1870, the advance of the Prussian troops toward Paris forced the Pissarro family to flee to the deep countryside near Brittany, where their friend Ludovic Piette had a large farm. Julie Vellay, Pissarro’s partner (and soon his wife), was already eight months pregnant when they fled. She gave birth to the couple’s third child and second daughter, Adèle-Emma, in Montfoucault on October 21, 1870. The infant died less than three weeks later and was buried in the Piette family plot on the farm. Pissarro seems to have ceased attempting to join the French army to fight against Germany in response to the repeated pleas of his mother, who insisted that he was not French—Pissarro was, in fact, a Danish citizen until his death—and thus should not put himself in harm’s way. Camille, Julie, and their children fled France in early December 1870 to the comparative safety of England.

Pissarro thrived in Britain. He spoke fluent English, and his mother, half sister, and brother-in-law were already living there, in the London suburb of Upper Norwood, which had a relatively large Jewish population. The family lived first in the neighboring suburb of Lower Norwood, but shortly after their arrival moved to a small house or apartment at Canham’s Dairy on Westow Hill, which was a short walk from the famed Crystal Palace (see fig. 4.1 and fig. 4.2). Early in 1871 the family moved again, this time to another house in Upper Norwood at 2 Chatham Terrace, where Pissarro painted his second view of this remarkable structure, a smaller painting that focused on Isambard Kingdom Brunel’s spectacular water towers rather than the Crystal Palace itself (fig. 4.3 [PDRS 184]). Pissarro was familiar with glass buildings of this type, having attended the Paris Expositions of 1855 and 1867, and he clearly felt the need to record this marvel of modern architecture and symbol of contemporary life in an equally modern manner. The Crystal Palace was designed and built in a very short period for the first World’s Fair, 1851’s Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of All Nations (“The Great Exhibition”), held in Hyde Park. The work of Joseph Paxton, it was dubbed the “Crystal Palace” by the editor of Punch, Douglas Jerrold, for its iron-and-glass structure. In 1854, after the exposition closed, it was dismantled, enlarged, and re-erected on a permanent basis in Upper Norwood, attracting visitors from all over the world. The move was financed by railroad companies, which had constructed two new stations in the formerly sleepy suburb to bring tourists from central London. This development made Upper Norwood a perfect place to find short-term housing and to travel easily back and forth to the center of the city.

Pissarro must have begun to paint immediately upon his arrival in England because two works, a snowy landscape and an image of Upper Norwood, were included in the catalogue of an exhibition organized by the Paris dealer Paul Durand-Ruel at the German Gallery (168 New Bond Street), which opened on March 6, 1871—less than three months after he moved to London. Indeed, once the Pissarro family was settled, Camille, stimulated by the change of scenery, took almost immediately to the outdoors to set up his easel. The present work undoubtedly dates from those months because it was painted in a spot on the main road in front of the Crystal Palace (see fig. 4.1 and fig. 4.4). In Fox Hill in Upper Norwood, Effect of Snow (fig. 4.5 [PDRS 180]), the houses of the well-to-do appear to be clearly situated atop a hill, as the road winds down to the foreground of the picture, reaching its apex in the midground. All is serene except for three people on the road: a man in a top hat walking up the hill, away from the viewer, and a pair of women in what seem to be dresses, shawls, and hats (indicative of a cold winter day) approaching the bottom of the slope, toward the viewer. Many of Pissarro’s Louveciennes landscapes feature similar perspectives and depictions of dusty roads.

By contrast, the Art Institute’s painting of the Crystal Palace, also viewed from Fox Hill, likely features a busy Upper Norwood boulevard, with well-heeled Londoners and tourists strolling during a cool but sunny spring afternoon with a breeze strong enough to make the multicolored flag stand out against the icy-blue clouds and minty-green glass of the Crystal Palace. The composition emphasizes the human population and the domestic architecture of the area more prominently than the Crystal Palace itself. Fox Hill and its surrounding areas in Upper Norwood clearly housed southeast London’s wealthier classes, as attested by the well-dressed families, horse-drawn carriages, baby strollers, clean streets, and neatly trimmed vegetation flanking the stone wall. Pissarro’s decision to paint the Crystal Palace as a part of the neighborhood instead of as the focal point of the work likely stemmed from his being a resident of the area. In April 1892 Charles Saunier described Pissarro’s 1871 works featuring London’s suburbs in the Revue indépendante: “Camille Pissarro visited London and strove to communicate the novel charm of the aristocratic English countryside.” It is clear that the artist, despite living near a marvel of modern architecture, strove to convey something closer to home with his multiple views of Fox Hill and its inhabitants. He worked on a pre-primed canvas possibly purchased from a London artist’s supply shop, most likely when he was in the company of his friend Claude Monet, who spoke no English and relied on Pissarro to translate. Indeed, Monet used a pre-primed and stretched canvas made from the same bolt of linen when he left London for Holland in 1871 (see Weave in the technical report). The Crystal Palace was painted over an apparently short period of time in three or more working sessions, with time to dry between each campaign (see Paint Layer in the technical report). The building is summarily but accurately painted, recording the walkway on top of the central nave in dark paint separately from the vaulted facade, which appears in shadow (fig. 4.6). The vast water tower, which Pissarro was to paint a few months later from the family’s second home in Upper Norwood (fig. 4.3), appears through the glass nave, with its shadow falling near it. Even the flagpole and its immense, unidentifiable flag can be seen in old photographs and illustrations of the building (fig. 4.7, fig. 4.8 and fig. 4.9), suggesting that Pissarro was faithful to all the main aspects of his view.

Pissarro emphasized the human population on the large road in front of the building by letting the glass structure almost disappear into the cloud-filled sky. He chose the effet of a cold, blustery morning, during which the sun has managed to peak brightly through the clouds, casting almost caricatural shadows, such as those of the family on the sidewalk on the right side of the composition (see fig. 4.10). Oddly, other figures have no such strong shadows, indicating that Pissarro painted them at different times or under different light conditions. Looking carefully at this suburban landscape, we can count more than forty figures, several horses, open and closed carriages, and a pram. All of this activity highlights both the presence of the tourist attraction and the fact that there was a railroad station just beyond the houses on the right (see fig. 4.11).

This picture may easily be considered Pissarro’s earliest cityscape and scene of modern life. Although he had painted scenes of Paris at least twice before, these are set in Montmartre and are essentially un-peopled. The only precursors of The Crystal Palace in his oeuvre are his many representations of the relatively busy route de Versailles in Louveciennes, on which the family had lived for a little more than a year before going to London. Yet this French street was decidedly more rural, and in several of Pissarro’s depictions of it (see fig. 4.12, fig. 4.13, and fig. 4.14 [PDRS 138, 140–41]), there are more agricultural carts pulled by farm horses and older black stagecoaches than fashionable leisure equipment and fancy baby carriages. On the other hand, in the London picture there is an undeniable sense of modernity, and the women are fashionably dressed in ways that were completely new for Pissarro’s landscapes. As such, the work relates more to the 1867 paintings of Paris by Pissarro’s friends Monet and Pierre-Auguste Renoir than to anything in his own career. The canvas also looks forward to the later urban landscapes painted in Paris (see cat. 13; The Place du Havre, Paris; 1893), Rouen, and the port cities in the north of France.

Commentators have long noted that Pissarro effectively deemphasized the Crystal Palace in favor of the masonry walls and houses across the street from it. This has been seen as a kind of pictorial repudiation of the very modernity that the artist attempted to describe, as Pissarro also painted a locomotive cutting through a hilly green English landscape and was, even later in his career, rather fixated on depicting smokestacks and factory chimneys, also major signs of cultural change. It is safe to assume, as Joachim Pissarro has asserted, that the artist’s works took a resolutely modernist turn during his short stay in London, prompted by his consideration of the revolutionary symbol of the railroad in modern paintings and its connotations of industrialization and cultural progress. In much the same way, Pissarro’s two views of the Crystal Palace’s glass-and-iron structure represent an imposing symbol of progress, this time in modern architecture.  
Richard R. Brettell

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Pissarro began this composition with a charcoal or black chalk underdrawing on a standard-size, commercially primed canvas with a white, three-layer preparation. Evidence of the underdrawing is somewhat visible in infrared examination and in small gaps in the paint layer, but the thickly modeled upper layers obscure the bulk of it. The absence of large compositional changes and the clarity of the composition in X-ray and transmitted-infrared examination suggest that the artist executed a full underdrawing, including some of the large figures and even their shadows, before painting. Pissarro appears to have reinforced this drawing with beige or buff underpaint along the edges of forms, painting up to but not over the original drawing. After laying in flat planes of color throughout, he finished the composition in a series of wet-in-wet campaigns, working large areas of the canvas, such as the sky, in a single session. Changes to the composition include moving the right edge of the Crystal Palace slightly to the left during the execution of the sky, and making small adjustments to the horse-drawn carriage at left and some of the gabled buildings at right. The artist also appears to have painted out shrubs and other green foliage in favor of individual tree branches at the far right. The tree branches themselves appear to be some of the last additions to the work, as the paint catches only the high points of the dried brushstrokes beneath. The painting is currently lined, with the original tacking margins removed, and varnished.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 4.15).

Signed and dated: C. Pissarro 1871 (lower left, in warm-gray paint) (fig. 4.16 and fig. 4.17).

Flax, commonly known as linen (estimated).

The original size of the canvas is not clear, as the edges were trimmed in a previous conservation treatment (see Conservation History), but the current size is 47 × 73.2 cm. This most closely corresponds to a no. 20 seascape vertical (marine basse) standard-size (72.9 × 48.6 cm) canvas.

Plain weave. Average thread count (standard deviation): 14.0V (0.5) × 15.5H (0.6) threads/cm. The vertical threads were determined to correspond to the warp and the horizontal threads to the weft. A warp-thread-count match between this painting and Claude Monet’s Windmills in the Westzijderveld near Zaandam (1871; Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam) was identified.

As the tacking margins were removed as part of an earlier conservation campaign (see Conservation History), much information about the canvas itself and its original stretching has been lost. The warp-angle map (fig. 4.18) shows rather uneven cusping of the vertical (warp) threads on either side of the work, while the weft-angle map (fig. 4.19) shows a pronounced downward distortion of the horizontal threads toward the lower corners of the painting. This downward pulling is also discernible in the X-ray. The warp-angle map also highlights deformations in the upper left quadrant; looking closely at the X-ray in this area, there appear to be a number of weft thread repairs, possibly the result of small tears in the canvas in this area (fig. 4.20). As the ground and paint layers seem unaffected, it is likely this occurred before the canvas was primed. Since the canvas is commercially primed and now lined, it is unclear how visible this defect would have been, or whether Pissarro would have noticed it when he purchased the canvas.

Current stretching: The painting was restretched and the tacking margins removed when it was lined at an unknown date. The stretcher does not appear to be original and may date from this lining (see Conservation History).

Original stretching: Based on cusping visible in the X-ray, the original tacks were placed approximately 4–7 cm apart on the sides and about 10 cm apart on the top and bottom.

Current stretcher: Five-member keyable stretcher with vertical crossbar. Depth: 2.3 cm.

Original stretcher: Unknown.

No manufacturer’s or supplier’s marks were observed during the current examination or documented in previous examinations.

Not determined (probably glue).

The ground is a three-layer commercially applied preparation that is smooth and moderately thick, ranging from approximately 45–115 µm in thickness. The chunky, lowest layer is highly irregular and may have been applied primarily to fill in the canvas texture. The middle layer contains particles of varying sizes but is relatively even in overall thickness, while the top layer contains the finest particles and appears the smoothest (fig. 4.21).

The ground appears almost white in stereomicroscopic examination, with a few dark particles visible (fig. 4.22). In cross-sectional analysis, the lowest layer of the ground appears almost brown; this color is the result of the composition of the ground and saturation by the medium and possibly the lining material. The middle layer of the ground appears slightly off-white, while the thin upper layer is white (fig. 4.23).

The ground is a three-layer commercial preparation: the lowest layer is predominantly chalk (calcium carbonate) with minor amounts of lead white, barium sulfate, silica, and bone black; the middle layer is a mixture of lead white and chalk with small amounts of barium sulfate and trace amounts of silica and bone black; and the top layer is predominantly lead white with trace amounts of silica and barium sulfate. The binder of all layers is estimated to be oil.

Infrared examination indicates that Pissarro executed a contour sketch directly on top of the ground outlining the architecture (fig. 4.24). At left, he began with long, straight lines that establish architectural perspective. The presence of thin paint along the edges of forms and the absence of major changes in the X-ray and transmitted infrared suggest that, although it may be obscured in infrared and microscopic examination, the other features in the painting, including the larger figures, houses, and architectural elements at the right, were also sketched prior to execution (fig. 4.25). The opacity and pigments of subsequent paint layers mask the full extent of compositional planning.

Due to the thickness of the paint, the underdrawing is mostly obscured and has been picked up in the application of subsequent paint layers throughout. Small skips in the paint layer reveal that the underdrawing in the architectural forms at left was done in charcoal or black chalk; it is unclear wether it was applied dry or in a fluid medium (fig. 4.26).

While there are changes between the planning and painting stages, there do not appear to be pentimenti within the drawing (see Paint Layer).

Pissarro began this composition by reinforcing and in some cases altering the shapes established in the black contour drawing with buff-colored paint (fig. 4.27). This underpainting is particularly visible in the upper sections of the Crystal Palace itself, in the gray-blue area at the horizon, and in the pyramidal tops of the posts along the sidewalk at right. The reinforcing of contours appears to extend to the very inside edge of the drawn lines in the palace but not to cover them, and it served to solidify the perspective, sometimes through subtle changes such as those on the far left of the composition. After this reinforcing, the artist then began to lay in these spaces in relatively flat, opaque paint layers; the painted shapes come up to but not over the drawn lines, creating a characteristic effect visible in the X-ray and transmitted-infrared images: the edges of forms appear in stark contrast to the forms they surround due to the thinness of paint over the drawn lines (fig. 4.28). The initial laying in of colors appears to feature tones that are slightly muted versions of the local colors later used to model the forms. Once the upper paint layers were added, the gaps between compositional elements were closed, and almost none of the ground or original black drawing was left visible.

The X-ray and transmitted infrared images reveal slight changes to the composition. The right edge of the Crystal Palace once extended slightly past its current right edge toward center; to alter the profile of this building, Pissarro simply painted over the edges with additional sky paint.

The horse-drawn carriage at left appears to be a late addition and was originally slightly closer to the viewer; the transmitted-infrared image shows a confusing array of thin strokes in the vicinity of the horses’ legs. Between the somewhat monochromatic laying in and wet-in-wet modeling stages, the eaves below the gabled roofs at right were diminished, and the full foliage at the far right was replaced by a bare, more minimal treatment of the branches. In the X-ray, the eave of the right building and its left edge appear further to the right, while in transmitted infrared, the left edges of both buildings appear further to the left and the eaves lower and less prominent. The far right trees appear as generalized shapes in the X-ray and are underpainted in a brownish-gray color applied with a wider, flat-tipped brush (fig. 4.29); these directional strokes are still visible in raking light in both the trees right of center and the tree at the far right edge that has been largely painted out. They were initially constructed as solid masses, as if there were leaves present, in a style more akin to the treatment of the shrubs in front of them. As Pissarro modeled the buildings at the right, covering much of these early shapes, he replaced them with individually articulated, leafless branches. At the far right, the X-ray also shows curvilinear forms that suggest additional shrubs; in some areas, muted green paint is visible beneath the reddish-brown color of the buildings (fig. 4.30).

The X-ray and infrared images also make clear which features in the painting were determined earlier and which were added at later stages. In addition to the buildings, the horizon line, most of the trees and shrubs at the right, the group of larger figures in the right foreground and their shadows, both horse-drawn carriages at left, and the two women pushing the stroller left of center, were all established very early in the process. The edge of the sidewalk at right and its angle into space, as well as the lampposts, appear to be part of the upper layers, although the technical images reveal no obvious changes to their placements. The rest of the smaller figures and the adjustments to the horse-drawn carriage at right were executed on top of the preexisting sidewalk; looking at the area in raking light, the thick, directional strokes of the sidewalk clearly pass under the figures at left (fig. 4.31).

Much of the upper modeling was executed wet-in-wet over preexisting drawing and underpainting. As mentioned above, the underdrawing, the underpainting, and the borders between compositional elements are almost entirely covered in these stages. This late phase also included the changes to the profile of the Crystal Palace, the horse-drawn carriage at left, and the articulation of many of the smaller figures throughout the foreground. Looking closely at the edges of forms, it seems that although Pissarro worked broad areas in a single sitting, the upper layers were completed in a series of steps. The clouds and sky, for example, were executed after the foreground and appear to have been brought around, and sometimes partially over, the various buildings. The paint is relatively thick, with a paste-like consistency that often retained the mark of the flat-tipped brushes Pissarro favored in many areas (fig. 4.32). The stiffness of the paint is apparent in passages where the underlying paint was somewhat dry and the artist dragged a brush across the surface, catching only the high points of the ridges beneath; the tree branches, added as an almost last step, were executed in this way (fig. 4.33). In some areas, the artist may have added a small amount of medium or spirits to thin the paint sufficiently to lay flat, adding new colors to existing layers and creating vibrant wet-in-wet swirls (fig. 4.34).

Mostly flat brushes, with strokes up to 1.0 cm wide.

Analysis indicates the presence of the following pigments: lead white, zinc white, emerald green, viridian, ultramarine blue, bone black, vermilion, red lake, iron oxide red and/or yellow, zinc yellow, chrome yellow, and possibly chrome orange.

Although the palette seems subdued, the painting features complex mixtures throughout. Most colors are mixed with white, illustrating the tonally unifying effect of peinture claire. Looking at the dark green at right under the microscope, for example, black, yellow, and red particles are clearly visible (fig. 4.35). A bluish-gray tone indicating the silhouetted buildings along the horizon contains primarily lead white and zinc white, with some ultramarine blue and vermilion, small amounts of red lake, and a trace of bone black (fig. 4.36).

Oil (estimated).

The painting has an overall synthetic varnish that was applied in 1974 to replace a discolored natural-resin varnish. It is, however, unclear if that varnish was original; as the painting had been lined and heavily retouched, it is likely that that varnish dates from previous restoration. It is unclear whether Pissarro would have varnished this painting.

The painting was examined in June 1970 and found to be wax-resin lined and stapled to a five-member keyable stretcher with ten keys. At this time it was also noted that the tacking margins had been removed in previous treatment, the paint layer was abraded and cracking with active cleavage and flake losses, and there was also much overpaint and a heavy discolored natural-resin varnish. In 1974 the work was treated and active flaking consolidated. The painting was also cleaned of its varnish and overpaint and given a synthetic varnish (polyvinyl acetate AYAA, followed by inpainting, a layer of methacrylate resin L-46, and a final coat of AYAA).

The painting is currently wax-resin lined and planar; the tacking margins were removed and the lining canvas is stapled to a five-member keyable stretcher with a vertical crossbar. The painting has a long history of overall cracking, cupped paint, flake losses, and cleavage, seen in the raking-light image (fig. 4.37). The lifting paint appears to be an inherent problem caused by poor adhesion between the ground and paint, coupled with ground cracking. There is an overall network of cracks, many with raised edges, and periodic losses throughout. One larger loss of note is in the rectangular building in the blue-gray area near the horizon line. A few minor losses are retouched, as is the cut edge around the perimeter. The painting was previously noted as having a great deal of overpaint; residues may be present, especially in the gray-blue band near the horizon line at center and in the clouds near the top. There is some blanching, especially in the clouds; it is unclear wether this blanching is associated with the varnish or the paint layers. The work has an overall synthetic varnish that imparts some saturation and an even gloss, with residues of an older, discolored varnish in the interstices of the paint, and many cotton fibers adhered to the surface.  
Kelly Keegan

Current frame: The frame is not original to the painting. It is a French, Louis XIV, ogee frame with lambrequin corner and rosette-and-shell center cartouches connected by c-scrolls and floral and foliate ornament, and a leaf-tip sight molding. The frame has water gilding, with oil gilding on the sanded frieze, over red-brown bole on gesso. Very little of the original gilding survives, as large portions of the frame have either been regessoed or overgilded; the frieze, for example, has an additional layer of sanded gilding over the original. The original carved oak moldings are mitered. The frame was resized for this painting by cutting and shortening the vertical legs on each side of the center cartouche. The oak moldings were planed flat on the back and glued to a back frame. The molding, from the perimeter to the interior, is fillet; ovolo with running ovate; scotia side; ogee face rounded over at the perimeter and quirked at the interior, with projecting lambrequin corner cartouches on a diamond bed with punched centers, and rosette-and-shell center cartouches on a plain bed, connected by c-scrolls and floral and foliate ornament on a quadrillage bed; ovolo; sanded frieze; and ogee sight molding with leaf-tip ornament on a straight-lined bed (fig. 4.38).

Previous frame (installed by 1967): The work was previously housed in what appears to have been a late-nineteenth- or early-twentieth-century reproduction of a Louis XIV ogee frame with projecting corner and center cartouches and connecting ornament and an independent liner (fig. 4.39).  
Kirk Vuillemot

It is possible that this painting contains the lead white and zinc white mixture found in other Pissarro works throughout the 1870s and 1880s. Bomford first observed, “This [mixture of lead- and zinc-based whites] is most likely to be a paint manufacturer’s mixture: there would be no reason for Pissarro himself to combine the two pigments, and artist’s tube paints consisting of several different whites and inerts were marketed in the second half of the nineteenth century.” See David Bomford, Jo Kirby, John Leighton, and Ashok Roy, Art in the Making: Impressionism, exh. cat. (National Gallery/Yale University Press, 1990), p. 66. For a table of paintings in other collections in which this mixture was found, see Lydia Gutierrez and Aviva Burnstock, “Technical Examination of Works by Camille and Lucien Pissarro,” Art Matters: Netherlandish Technical Studies in Art 5 (2013), p. 4, table 2. This mixture was also identified in Snow at Louveciennes (c. 1870; cat. 3), Young Peasant Having Her Coffee (1881; cat. 10) and, Haymaking at Éragny (1892; cat. 12).

As chrome yellow and chrome orange share the same chemical makeup, they are not distinguishable by elemental analysis alone and must be visually differentiated based on their color. The presence of chrome orange in a sample from the present painting was based on the simultaneous identification of lead and chromium by XRF and SEM/EDX, along with visual observation of the orange color of the inclusions.
